security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown content with usage examples for the samber/lo Go library. No executable code, no file system access, no network calls, no external commands.

content.value_statement: Go developers need concise, readable collection operations but writing loops for filtering, mapping, and transforming data adds boilerplate. The samber/lo library provides Lodash-style generic functions that make common operations simple and expressive.
limitations: Only provides guidance for samber/lo library functions
Does not execute Go code or verify implementations

use_cases.title: Simplify collection operations
use_cases.description: Replace verbose for-loops with Filter, Map, and Reduce for cleaner data transformations

use_cases.title: Handle optional values safely
use_cases.description: Use lo.Must and error handling patterns for initialization code with clear panic behavior

use_cases.title: Transform data structures
use_cases.description: Convert between data models efficiently using GroupBy, Uniq, and custom mapping functions

prompt_templates.title: Filter data
prompt_templates.prompt: Use lo.Filter to get even numbers from a slice of integers

prompt_templates.title: Transform collections
prompt_templates.prompt: Use lo.Map to square each value in a slice of integers

prompt_templates.title: Find matching element
prompt_templates.prompt: Use lo.Find to get the first value greater than 10 from a slice

prompt_templates.title: Group data
prompt_templates.prompt: Use lo.GroupBy to group a User slice by their Age field

output_examples.input: How do I filter even numbers from []int{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}?
output: lo.Filter(nums, func(x int, _ int) bool { return x%2 == 0 })

best_practices: Import the specific sub-packages you need (parallel, mutable, it) for better performance
Use the Must pattern only for initialization code where panics are acceptable
Prefer parallel processing with lop prefix for large datasets
anti_patterns: Using lo.Must in user-facing code where errors should be handled gracefully
Ignoring the second return value (ok) when using Find or other maybe functions
Using mutable operations on large slices without considering parallel processing

faq.question: What Go version is required?
faq.answer: Go 1.18 or higher is required for generics support used by samber/lo.

faq.question: What operations are available?
faq.answer: Filter, Map, Find, GroupBy, Uniq, Must, and many more for collections and error handling.

faq.question: How to install the library?
faq.answer: Run: go get github.com/samber/lo@v1 to add the library to your project.

faq.question: Is data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No. This skill only provides documentation. The library itself runs locally in your Go programs.

faq.question: What if I get compile errors?
faq.answer: Ensure Go >= 1.18 and run go mod tidy to sync dependencies after adding the library.

faq.question: How does this compare to standard library?
faq.answer: samber/lo provides more expressive APIs than slices package but adds a dependency to your project.
